text:
That won't work <@U016TGY3676>, with middleware (I believe) it only fires on startup, so that will just bypass any markets with no (marketbook in this case rather than catalogue).

Whilst realistically it should be easy enough to filter out rogue orders later on, I wanted to do as much processing as possible here as it occurs on startup (if its possible that is).

elements.text: That won't work

, with middleware (I believe) it only fires on startup, so that will just bypass any markets with no (marketbook in this case rather than catalogue).

text: My understanding is that middleware is called on every update?

elements.text: My understanding is that middleware is called on every update?

text: The way the orders are processed it appeared to me as though middleware fires once on startup and for updates during running background workers get called every x seconds. But it's very possible I've got that wrong (although then I would expect the above to work, i.e. only updating if MarketBook is not None), but it never occurs!

text:
and unless I'm being dumb (which is quite possible) I can't figure out a smart way to filter it out

In the end, I used this approach you suggested, which appears to do the job:

```        if market.market_book is None:
            market_book = self.flumine.client.betting_client.betting.list_market_book(market_ids=[market.market_id])[0]
        else:
            market_book = market.market_book

        runner_list = [(str(runner.selection_id), str(runner.handicap)) for runner in market_book.runners if runner.status == 'ACTIVE']

        for current_order in resp.orders:
            if (str(current_order.selection_id), str(current_order.handicap)) in runner_list:```

text: From (very) vague memory, I'm fairly sure that betfair flag up markets that may have runners settled before closure. Not sure if there's a flag in the API, but I'm reasonably confident that there's something in the market description along the lines of "runners may be settled before market close"???

text: Looking at that graph I wonder if some partial automation was used? Either that or some blindly following back bots got involved? Or maybe 2 players working together? This is an easy play for a manual player to make but it's hard to get the benefit from it and you wouldn't want to be sat there for days on end waiting for your chance.

text: Has anyone used imap_tools? I've got it to loop through emails but I want to limit it to emails received since 1/6/21. According to the docs date_gte should do that but it just hangs. Here's the line: for msg in mailbox.fetch(date_gte=datetime.date(2021, 6, 1)):

text:
Your code as written should be returning a "TypeError: fetch() got an unexpected keyword argument 'date_gte'" message. Query style search criteria need to be wrapped in an AND, OR or NOT function. This works for me

```from imap_tools import AND
...
for msg in mailbox.fetch(AND(date_gte=datetime.date(2021, 6, 1))):```

elements.text: Your code as written should be returning a "TypeError: fetch() got an unexpected keyword argument 'date_gte'" message. Query style search criteria need to be wrapped in an AND, OR or NOT function. This works for me
